holidays.name: Opposite Day
holidays.description: A day to do everything backwards or oppositely ‚Äî say the opposite of what you mean, wear your clothes inside out, or just flip your usual routine upside down!
holidays.origin: The exact origin is unclear, but it emerged as a playful concept in American culture, popularized by schools and children in the mid-20th century.
holidays.funFact: Despite being unofficial and a bit confusing, many schools celebrate Opposite Day annually as a way to spark creativity and silliness.

holidays.name: National Irish Coffee Day
holidays.description: A day to celebrate the iconic cocktail made with hot coffee, Irish whiskey, sugar, and topped with cream. A perfect cozy drink to warm up January!
holidays.origin: Irish Coffee was first made in the 1940s by Joe Sheridan at Foynes Airport in Ireland to warm up cold travelers.
holidays.funFact: Irish Coffee was declared an 'Official Irish Cocktail' by the Irish government, and the original recipe is still closely guarded.

holidays.name: Burns Night (Scottish celebration)
holidays.description: Celebrating the life and poetry of Scotland's national poet Robert Burns, usually with haggis, whisky, and recitals of his famous works.
holidays.origin: Commemorates Robert Burns‚Äô birthday (born January 25, 1759), widely celebrated in Scotland and worldwide by Scottish communities.
holidays.funFact: Burns suppers traditionally include a ceremonial "Address to the Haggis" and the drinking of Scotch whisky amid recitations.

holidays.name: National Fun at Work Day
holidays.description: Encourages workers to enjoy a little levity during their workday ‚Äî games, jokes, and any fun activity that breaks up the monotony!
holidays.origin: Created to promote a positive work environment and stress reduction.
holidays.funFact: Some companies hold elaborate celebrations, including costume contests or silly awards, to mark the day.
